physDesc.p: This letter is one page long. The words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written at the top, along with the date.

div.p: I will do Eunice Tietjens’ book for you as soon as I can. I probably shall not be able to get at it for a couple of weeks, as I am now in the last finishing touches of my own book, which must go to press about the first of July.

I am awfully disappointed that you refused Richard Hunt's “Gas-Lamp Ghost.” You remember that I spoke to you about it when I was in Chicago and told you how very good I thought it was. You asked me to have him send it on to you, and of course, I told him, and he says that you returned it to him recently alleging as a reason, that gas lamps were out of date. Dear Harriet, we live in an out-of-date part of the world, and there are gas lamps all up and down our parkways and through most of the streets of this town in which I live. Of course, they are not the old flame gas jets, but incandescent mantle lights. Mr. Hunt's poem is, therefore, not only beautiful but absolutely up-to-date. I confess that your refusing it has hurt my feelings not a little. When Ezra sends you poems, I think you usually accept them, but apparently when I take the trouble to send you poems you feel no confidence in my judgment and turn them down. I think you have made a great mistake, for to my mind, that is one of the most beautiful poems of its type which I have seen at all. I heartily wish (sic) that I had written it.

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: Please send me three June number of "Poetry"
